thread.title: Tassal to be probed over witness pulling out of aquaculture inquiry
thread.title_full: Tassal to be probed over witness pulling out of aquaculture inquiry

author: Emilie Gramenz
title: Tassal to be probed over witness pulling out of aquaculture inquiry

organizations.name: parliament the environment and communications committee

text:
Map: TAS 
A Senate committee will investigate whether representatives of Australia's largest salmon farmer, Tassal, improperly influenced a Tasmanian mussel farmer to back out of appearing before an inquiry into the aquaculture industry. 
A 2016 Four Corners report on Tasmania's salmon farming industry aired the allegation that Tassal "bought" the silence of Dover mussel farmer Warwick Hastwell who had made a submission to the 2015 Senate inquiry. 
In his written submission, Mr Hastwell had claimed contamination from nearby fish pens destroyed his mussel farm but he did not appear in person at the inquiry as scheduled. 
During the Four Corners report, Mr Hastwell told the ABC's Caro Meldrum-Hanna he had accepted a deal from Tassal which "bought his silence". 
Meldrum-Hanna: Why did you accept that? 
Mr Hastwell: As a husband and wife business, we were standing to lose a large amount of money and capital investment and we just couldn't afford ... to walk away from that much of a loss. 
Mr Hastwell said in the lead-up to the 2015 inquiry his lawyer received correspondence from Tassal, reminding Mr Hastwell and his then wife and partner of their "obligations not to make disparaging statements whether in relation to the Senate Enquiry [sic] or to the media or otherwise". 
A day later, he said, Tassal wrote again, attempting to withdraw the deal with Mr Hastwell. 
Mr Hastwell told Four Corners he decided to pull out of his scheduled appearance at the inquiry. 
Meldrum-Hanna: Do you believe that you were prevented or coerced from giving evidence at the inquiry? 
Mr Hastwell: Yes. 
Meldrum-Hanna: Do you have the material to back that up? 
Mr Hastwell: Yes I do. 
Meldrum-Hanna: In what form is that? 
Mr Hastwell: I have copies of emails and letters from withdrawing the offer because of [how] it could be construed. I think they'd woken up to the fact that what they were doing was essentially illegal and they thought they better try and get out of it. But as I said, you know, … we'd already accepted the deal. 'Witness may have been improperly influenced' 
The Senate voted today to refer the allegations to the Standing Committee of Privileges, which investigates conduct that may obstruct the work of the Senate. 
On Wednesday night, the Senate president, Tasmanian Senator Stephen Parry, told Parliament the Environment and Communications Committee had reported that the allegations may have substance. 
"Having taken the necessary steps, the committee has concluded that the witness may have been improperly influenced," he said. 
"The only remaining remedy to address those concerns is the use of the Senate's contempt powers." 
The matter will now be investigated further, which will likely involve submissions from both parties and closed hearings. Privileges Committee 'almost like a court of law' 
Former Senate president Paul Calvert, who was a Tasmanian senator for two decades, said referrals to the Privileges Committee were not common. 
"It's something that's not used a lot, but is regarded very highly by all members of the Senate," he said. 
"It's made up of members of all parties and is seen as an independent body. 
"It's almost like a court of law — the Priveleges Committee will consider what action may need to be taken if there is found to be a breach of privilege. 
"They do have penalties, and if it's a serious breach, then other action can be taken." 
A spokesman for Tassal said the company was not yet in a position to comment. 
"It is difficult for Tassal to comment too specifically as the company is yet to receive any formal instructions from the committee," he said. 
Mr Hastwell declined to comment.
